NEET_Biology_Teacher_Note: Hello future doctors! Projectile motion is a favorite in the NEET physics section. Pay close attention to the range, maximum height, and time of flight formulas. Remember that $V_x$ never changes!

Previous_Year_Questions.Question: A projectile is fired at an angle of $45^\circ$ with the horizontal. Elevation angle of the projectile at its highest point as seen from the point of projection is:
The horizontal range and the maximum height of a projectile are equal. The angle of projection of the projectile is:
A ball is projected with a velocity, $10\text{ m/s}$, at an angle of $60^\circ$ with the vertical direction. Its speed at the highest point of its trajectory will be:
Previous_Year_Questions.Answer: a (Note: angle is with vertical, so angle with horizontal is $30^\circ$)

Previous_Year_Questions.Question: For a projectile, the ratio of maximum height reached to the square of flight time is ($g = 10\\text{ ms}^{-2}$):
The maximum range of a gun on horizontal terrain is $16\\text{ km}$. If $g = 10\\text{ m/s}^2$, then muzzle velocity of a shell must be:
Two projectiles are fired from the same point with the same speed at angles of projection $60^\circ$ and $30^\circ$ respectively. Which one of the following is true?

Options.a: Their maximum height will be same
Options.c: Their landing speed will be different
Options.d: Their time of flight will be same

Previous_Year_Questions.Question: A body is projected with velocity $u$ such that its horizontal range is twice the maximum height. Its horizontal range is:
Which of the following remains constant during the projectile motion?

A projectile is thrown in the upward direction making an angle of $60^\circ$ with the horizontal direction with a velocity of $147\text{ ms}^{-1}$. Then the time after which its inclination with the horizontal is $45^\circ$ is:
The velocity of a projectile at the initial point $A$ is $(2i + 3j)\\text{ m/s}$. Its velocity (in m/s) at point $B$ (upon landing) is:

Student_Tips_on_Projectile_Motion.Tip_1: Constant Velocity: The horizontal component $(u \cos \theta)$ never changes throughout the motion because there is no horizontal acceleration.
Student_Tips_on_Projectile_Motion.Tip_2: Max Range: Range is maximum when the projection angle is $45^\circ$.
Student_Tips_on_Projectile_Motion.Tip_3: Complementary Angles: Projectiles fired at angles $\theta$ and $(90^\circ - \theta)$ with the same speed have the same horizontal range.
Student_Tips_on_Projectile_Motion.Tip_4: Peak Velocity: At the highest point, the velocity is not zero; it is equal to the horizontal component $(u \cos \theta)$.
Student_Tips_on_Projectile_Motion.Tip_5: Path Symmetry: The time taken to reach the maximum height is exactly half the total time of flight.
